title: Flashforge Creator X 3mm and other size Glass plate Shims for Z Axis.

description.text:
Users of Flashforge Creator X who prefer to use 3mm glass plate can use this shim to compensate for the glass plate thickness.  
Creator X build plate is much thicker than the wooden Creator so adjusting the screws would not work. Lowering build plate via adjustment screws requires shorter springs ( or a thinner hot plate ) which I do not have at the moment.  
Just remember that you will loose around 3 mm height using the shim.   
I made this design based on early models of Creator X as of Feb 2014.   
Updated to include other shim sizes
Made in 3Dsmax

title: Luverne Drop-Center bumper license plate light lens

description.text: I have a 1994 F-150 equipped with a Luverne 9408 8-inch drop-center bumper. After 23 Minnesota winters, the license plate lenses on the bumper have all but disintegrated. As such, there was nothing to diffuse the light from the bulbs, and the plate wasn't being illuminated hardly at all. After being given a verbal warning by a police officer who thought I didn't have lights on the plate at all, and discovering that Luverne doesn't make anything like this anymore, I decided just to make my own based on what was left of the originals rather than try to hunt down replacements that would fit.

title: Geeetech I3X Cooling Fan Bracket with touch probe mount for acrylic carriage

description.text:
A cooling fan (blower style) bracket that I remixed to accommodate the 8mm Acrylic carriage of the Geeetech Prusa I3 X. This is a remix of an already fantastic part originally designed for a printer with a metal carriage.

I thickened the part to 8mm, added a cutout for the rectangular tab that sticks out from the front of the acrylic carrier, widened the holes to accommodate the 40mm mount screw spacing and also shifted the holes to better align the fan output with the hot end.

The fan friction fits pretty good but if you need extra stability, I used a piece of double sided tape between the fan and the part.

Works with BLTouch or 3DTouch and offsets at about X:-28m Y:-43 from the tip.

Enjoy!

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3 X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with 'supports from build platform only' setting and manually add supports for center rectangle cutout if desired.

comments.text: I've printed this today for my i3X and while it fits on fine, the BLTouch is too high - about a cm higher than the nozzle. Any thoughts?

comments.text: My guess would be that your nozzle is much lower than mine.  Perhaps the nozzle throat is longer, have you upgraded or changed it?  I'm using the stock nozzle from Geeetech and there is only about 1 cm clearance between the bottom of the extruder and the top of the heater block.
comments.author: derekoh

comments.text: I'm using the stock nozzle too (from Dec '17).
comments.author: woundedknee

comments.text: That's it.  Your throat is longer than mine, they must have changed what they are sending.  I remixed this part and added the probe mount, the fan output should be almost even with the tip.  For reference, when my tip is at Z0, the lowest part of the part (fan outlet) is only 4mm from the bed.  I bought my printer in 2016

description.text:
Small Dremel bit holder.

I have made a bigger one - the dimensions are now correct and the holes for the bits are the correct size - I have also added more holes.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/08sgfeyHTvX
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4kiPJH6e2Ib

A 7.4V battery pack used with my FPV glasses, this can however also be used with other applications needing 7.4V. The pack can be charged through USB and has an LED voltage indicator for easy checking of battery voltage.

With 3500mAh, these are almost double the capacity of the Fatshark alternative USB battery.

Work in progress!

WARNING: Some electronic experience is needed, and soldering directly on 18650 Cells can be dangerous!

Installing the Electronics

The battery uses two 18650 LG Cells in series, in my case 3500mAh.

USB circuit to create 8.4V needed for the 2s BMS: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-lot-DC-DC-Adjustable-Boost-Module-2A-Boost-Plate-2A-Step-Up-Module-with-MICRO/32720724661.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.W93O5j

2s BMS: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2S-4A-7-4V-li-ion-BMS-PCM-battery-protection-board-bms-pcm-with-balancing-for/32378011228.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.W93O5j

LED Indicator for 2s: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1s-2s-3s-4s-5s-Lithium-Charging-Battery-Capacity-Percent-Level-LED-Indicator-New-XQ-7/32822497934.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.W93O5j

Instructions:

  1. The BMS and LED indicator is installed in the Battery holder part, and the batteries are installed.
  2. BMS and indicator circuit is soldered up to the batteris (WARNING: Soldering directly on battery terminals can be dangerous and/or decrease battery health, DO THIS AT YOUR OWN RISK!)
  3. USB Circuit is installed in the Shell, and is wired up to the rest of the electronics.
  4. Remember to install your output plug of your choice, I used a 5.5x2.1mm barrel connector, as most FPV goggles use this type.
  5. The two parts are closed and M3 bolts are installed in the three corners.

This is a work in progress, so things might not fit perfectly!

description.text:
My mom made a passing comment about getting water on her counter when she went to use the soap bottles, so this soap bottle drain came to mind. I designed it to be used with two 7cm wide circular shaped bottles with personally desired dimensions of 150mm X, 91.5mm Y, 33.2mm Z.

You will have to resize it as it loads into the slicer 750% smaller than my mentioned dimensions.

I've made hollows on the bottom four corners where you can glue in some rubber/silicone feet depending on the type of filament you decide to use.

I'd suggest you coat the entire thing in some kind of hydrophobic layer.

You could also add silicone/rubber/high friction strips to the top of the bottle risers if you want. Again depending on print material and alla that.

EDIT: noticed a small size anomaly, fixed.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4

Infill:

7%

Notes:

Cura sliced it up nicely and all the layers look well connected. That said, If there is a problem with the model, not your print settings, let me know.
As mentioned earlier I'd strongly recommend coating this in some kind of sealer since it is intended to be around water.

1. Started with a squished cylinder and stretched along the x axis.
  2. inset that face and extruded the border.
  3. rotated the cylinder 15 degrees.
  4. Starting from a cube i made the bottle risers and set them on top of the cylinder till they just barely sunk into the cylinders face.
  5. extruded the drain spout from the cylinder and adjusted everything accordingly.
  6. using another cube i made the bottom risers loosely based on vaulted ceiling columns.

I used an old power supply with 12 volts and 200mA (note polarity, too).
The LEDs consumpts about 20mA.

description.text:
I fell madly in love with the awesome Glock 17 replica by Eight_Props (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2284125). However, I really wanted a bit more flashy barrel instead. So, I've added a 1 mm deep external riffling, twisting 180 degrees down the barrel.

Since I also find, the internal riffling a bit too subtle, at least on my printer, I will be making a version with more pronounce grooves soon.

I've had the best result the barrel printed parallel to the print bed with supports.

Thanks to Eight_Props for the amazing model.

Update December 2017
So, I finally got around to design, test and upload the awesome Glock 17 barrel with both a decorative outer riffling and a more pronounced inner riffling, than that of the original file.
If you print with support inside the barrel, these are VERY hard to remove due to the rougher surface provided by the riffling.

title: Anet A8 Filament guide pully (2 versions)

description.text:
I tried some filament guides, but until now, every design had some disadvantages. I designed these guides so that the wheel(s) can spin during printing. This way, filament is not stuck in the guide. I printed and used both. I like the double wheel pully more, buth the single wheel print also works fine.

Printed with support. After printing, removed the support. Then carefully push a thin knive (stanly-knive) between the wheel(s) and supportstructure. After that, carefully spin the wheel(s) until they spin easy. I also needed to sand the wheel a bit to remove the support compleetly.

remixed_from.title: Robust and precise NEMA 17 steppers / belt tensioners

description.text:
Troublemaker is a derivative from the highly popular open-source 3D printer Ultimaker Original by active individuals of Drustvo Elektronikov Slovenije (hobby electronics society) designed for the members group 3D printer build lead by myself. With about 80 members very interested in having a 3D printer, we have incorporated modifications and improvements into a derivative design nicknamed Troublemaker.
The main differences from Ultimaker original are:
  • Improved enclosure design, allowing for easy heated chamber upgrade. The enclosure has been enlarged to house the bowden above print head, so only flat plexy pieces are needed to enclose it.
  • Added support to mount two extruders and reels for dual-print configuration.
  • Can support almost any printhead with a 3D printer mount, the main choice is E3D metal-only hotend, which performs very well with PLA and ABS. The use of EasyE3DMount design is suggested to mount it, the new version has magnetic mounted cooling fan for easy swapping of different fan duct designs and removing it.
  • Uses 3D printer electronics available at PlanetCNC, that is directly mounted into the front panel.
  • The design includes mostly widely available parts.
  • Belts and pulleys proposed for use are GT2, with PlanetCNC 3D printer carriage design, open belts can be used.
  • The print bead has been modified to use 3-point levelling and its sturdiness increased, however higher precision laser cutting is required for it.
  • PlanetCNC Extruder design uses a NEMA 17 stepper with planetary reductor, a more compact design compared to the original one.
  • Enclosure includes mounting holes for motor belt tensioner modification, Z switch adjustment modification.
  • Bottom side mounting holes for power supplies, stepper drivers.
  • Enclosure mounted mains IEC socket with a built in fuse and switch.
  • Mounting holes for cables.
  • Printers are fully stackable
    The documentation includes:
  • Bill of materials
  • Assembly instructions (Slovenian language only for now)
  • Laser cut drawings
    Notes:
    Power supply socket JR-101-1-FRSG-02

This printer is easy to construct once you have all the right parts. Sourcing them should be easy as they are all chosen to be available. Check your local 3D printer shops and online. The Bill of materials included in the files lists all the necessary parts.
  • Source the parts
  • Follow the photo-steps for assembly
  • Happily print
    Some ideas for suitable web shops.
    PlanetCNC web shop
    reprap.cc
    E3D online
    Ultimaker shop

Berd-Air Cooling tube

title: MIA LED LAMP Ver 1.0 for ANYCUBIC  I3 MEGA

description.text:
ANYCUBIC I3 MEGA LED Lamp Holder for RC LED Strip.

This is a basic simple LED light that needs no special dismantling of the hot end to fit LEDs inside.

The RC LED Strip is actually longer so it had to be cut down to fit the lamp holder. It can be connected to any 12V DC source. Either using the exisiting JST connector that comes with the RC LED strip to a mating connector of a 3S Li-Pol , as I am temporarily doing until I can connect it direct to the 12 volt power supply for continuous use. It can also be connected to a small AC to 12VDC ~ 1A dedicated wall transformer.

The lamp provides ample light to the work surface, since the Lamp is 6" long and is angled towards the back, with clearance on the sides so the machine homes safely. It connects direct via the 2 screws of the hot end enclosure at the front top.

I did another version which encompasses the whole perimeter of the hot end enclosure, like a range hood and although the light was more directed at the center of the part, under the hot end, it would block visual inspection of the first layers of the 3D print, so I opted for this version which I think is more practical. It still provides plenty light around the work area . I have other Lamp designs but have to tweak the files.

print_settings.Notes:: I was able to print the sponge with a resolution of 200 microns. You should not use a higher resolution, since it could lead to the problem that the smallest squares (4th iteration) cannot be resolved anymore.

description.text:
This thing is a printable version of the famous Menger sponge. The 3D model is iterated up to the 4th level.

Printing the Menger sponge is a challenging task due to the many overhangs. As it has already been shown, you can succeed if you cut the sponge in half; thus, you must print the *.stl file twice and glue it together. I've cut my model in a way, that only a minimal, barely noticeable area needs to be glued together.

The model has a relatively small size: The diagonal of the square is only 9.5cm. Yet, it should be no problem to scale the model up. But keep in mind, that printing this model takes a lot of time. Printing one half in its original size took me about 15 hours with a resolution of 200 microns.

Fun Fact about the Menger sponge: If you do an infinite iteration squence, you'll end up with a body of zero volume -- but the "square's" surface will have a size of infinity!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Supports might be needed for the "large" overhang of the center of the sponge. I managed to print it without supports. Depending on your printer's bridging abilities, you might consider supports.

Infill doesn't really matter. If you print with 2 or 3 perimeter shells, then you'll almost have automatically 100% infill due to the small layer volumes.

I was able to print the sponge with a resolution of 200 microns. You should not use a higher resolution, since it could lead to the problem that the smallest squares (4th iteration) cannot be resolved anymore.
Designing the Menger sponge is straightforward using Mathematica. Take a look at http://mathworld.wolfram.com/MengerSponge.html for detailled explanations.

Several different pieces of other mecha from video games along with some personal adjustments parted out to print fairly easily with a little support. This is intended for 15mm scale wargaming. You can see a human in 15mm scale next to the mech in the assembled image preview. I plan on basing it on two 50mm metal washers so that it's stable but still able to be placed around terrain on the table. You can scale it however you like of course, but I suggest basing it on something because I don't know how stable it's going to stand on it's own.

I have included a Gruntz stat card for use in your 15mm scale Gruntz games.

Check out my Blog where I talk more about 3D printing and painting wargame models.

description.text:
My friend has this weird case for a wine bottle. It's intended to protect and keep cool a bottle of wine while hiking. It's an insulating fabric/foam case on the outside, and used to have a rigid plastic hollow tube with freezer gel inside. That inner tube was cracked or lost, and he asked me to design a replacement.

He didn't care about cooling the wine, but wanted shock protection for the bottom portion of the bottle. He gave me rough measurements of the old one, and here we are.

Included is a tester piece with just two springy living hinges for dialing in settings before you commit to the entire diameter. I'm not sure if this is going to be widely helpful without protection for the neck, but you never know!

title: Shadespire Game Box PROTOTYPE (Work in Progress)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a prototype (V1.3) of a game box for the new Arena Combat game, Shadespire, made by Games Workshop.

This is my own design and I am uploading it so you guys and girls can print and use it for your own games. I will be working on updates as time goes on. If you have any comments, ideas or suggestions, feel free to leave a comment below.

The box includes;
Card and die space
Countersunk hole for card access
2 Wound Marker Columns
3 Glory Token Columns
1 Guard Token Column
1 Move/Charge Token Column
1 Activation token Column

I am holding onto the licencing of this design as I may approach GW about reproduction rights in the future, but feel free to use it in your own games.

description.text:
Replacement base pad for stock gsg/sig 1911 single stack magazines. Adds +4 capacity for a total of 14.

If you can source a stronger spring, it's probably worth while swapping the stock one out to prevent feeding issues. That said, it seems to be working fairly well without it, for myself.

Installation Instructions:

  • Remove original base pad by pushing pin in through the bottom and sliding pad forwards.
  • Remove the pin at the end of the spring and discard.
  • Push 3d printed base pad onto bottom of magazine.
  • Optionally insert a ~20mm M1.5 bolt through the hole in the back to lock the base plate into place (the base pad stays on with a friction fit fairly well, so this isn't strictly required, and hasn't been tested much).

comments.text: you wont be able to see through the camera bubble since it is one piece with the body.  and the antenna protector has no place to install the antenna. its solid to the body. and the rockets wont do jack to help there are just for show.
comments.author: dav88

comments.text: Plexiglass is optically clear, sorry I didn’t take the time to cut a hole for the bubble or antenna. As for the rockets they will in fact add stability. Any flow over a sphere creates conical vortices and a small amount of drag behind it, which flow to the coil which acts as a diffuser for the air flow to reduce any sudden pressure drop in turbulent flow. If your going to be salty about my design keep it to yourself bro it’s a simple contest

title: Ribbed Light Shade

description.text:
This is a light shade inspired by one I saw at a friends house that was a bit bigger. This was printed on a 200 x 200 bed so that was my restriction for the overall size. I printed 30 ribs and the top and bottom ring in wood fill pla, which I then sanded and stained before assembling and clear coating. The top ring is sized to fit a standard bayonet or edison screw light base with a screw on shade holder (as seen in one of the pictures). If you wanted more light and less shadow it could be printed in transparent pla/petg etc and I'm sure it would look nice.
The bulb I used is a Mirabella Vintage style filament 25W clear.

title: PVC Holder for Filament Storage Box

description.text:
The idea of the filament storage box is based on a YouTube video from Thomas Sanladerer. All I did, was to design a pipe holder part that will fit a PVC pipe with a 50mm outer diameter.

To make your own storage box you’ll need the following parts,

title: Nintendo Switch Joycon Grip and Game Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Modified my original switch game case to use as a travel joycon grip! Also now holds twice as many games! Perfect for travelling and playing on the go.

For the shell, I printed it vertically so there were no bridges or supports needed. The grip also has the same snap lock features that are on the real joycon grip and switch, so you have to use the release buttons on the back of the joycons to take them off of the grip. For the logo, I printed it out separately and gluing it onto the shell.

Note that there is a tab on one edge of each compartment on the case that works as a friction fit snap feature. Push the side of the game cartridge against that tab and pivot it into position to lock it into the case.

Update: I've fixed the updside down logo of the original version and uploaded a version without a logo at all in case you didn't want to include that part.

comments.text: This is absolutely genius. I can easily see a 3rd party company trying to nick this design!

Probably I overlook something, but I see no way of printing this without supports, even vertically.  How did you rotate it vertically: with the object put with one of the short sides to the bed, or with one of the long sides to the bed?  In both situations, still there is quite a distance to 'bridge'.  Thanks in advance for your answer.
comments.author: Sven_B

comments.text: Ah sorry, I actually made a change to the design which meant that you actually will either have a long bridge or need supports. I didn't update the text however to remove that sentence. I print it vertically with the short sides on the bed, so that the print will create a bridge between the front and back surface of the part. My printer is able to make that bridge with minimal drooping, but some printers might have trouble with it. I've also printed with supports, and the supports that Cura auto generates work fine from my tests.

I think drone flying should be an Olympic event and the Teal sport would be the ideal candidate for events like drone aerobatics, obstacle race and "race and target".

My design allows the pilot to fire 5mm plastic pellets using an air compression cartridge released through remote control. The design can hold 100 pellets that can travel up to 50
feet at 185mph. The key to this design is to maintain functionality but also keep the weight to a minimum.

The current design will allow one or several pellets to travel approximately 50 feet with 120PSI compression. I am collaborating with a designer so any reward for this design will be shared.

Its time to broaden the Teal market.

My design utilizes a standard 12g CO2 cartridge found in most stores. The 120 PSI air compression has a load to propel about 100 - 150 pellets.

The components total cost is $58 and as we refine this design to make it lighter, less metal components will be required. Here's the short list:

Pneumatic Solenoid valve + M4 screws
Cartridge intake Valve
1/4" pipe taps x2
1/4" plastic flexible hose
5.2mm barrel
5mm plastic pellets
CO2 12g cartridge

excel 10M 32.8Ft 6mm x 4mm Pneumatic Polyurethane PU Hose Tube Pipe Blue
amazon https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-32-8Ft-Pneumatic-Polyurethane-Hose/dp/B008MO66FO/ref=pd_bxgy_328_img_3?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=PGWK5XJV0EYP8PPDQAMS
https://www.amazon.com/4inch-Normally-Closed-Electric-Solenoid/dp/B00ON8XFSO
10 Pcs 1/4" PT Male Thread 6mm Push In Joint Pneumatic Connector Quick Fittings
https://www.amazon.com/Thread-Joint-Pneumatic-Connector-Fittings/dp/B009ITF6QC/ref=pd_bxgy_328_img_2?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=PGWK5XJV0EYP8PPDQAMS
https://www.ebay.com/itm/1-4-2-Way-Normally-Closed-Pneumatic-Electric-Solenoid-Air-Valve-12V-DC-6-5W-AF-/292295463578?_trksid=p5731.m3795
http://www.airsoftmegastore.com/100-Airsoft-12g-CO2-Cartridge-For-CO2-Guns-ACC-CO2CTG.aspx

Some parts can have lighter alternatives that you can find around the home. This is a fun assembly that will require minimal tools to put together including a hot glue gun.

The compressed air is released through the Pneumatic valve via a remote control signal. The Pneumatic valve will close once the electrical charge is gone so you can have single shots or large bursts. The pellet canister on the design can hold about 100 pellets.

How it works

Unscrew the pellet container on the model and fill with 100 pellets. Connect the CO2 cartridge to the cartridge valve. The Teal will require a remote controlled connection for the air release pneumatic valve. Once the remote control button is initiated, compressed air rapidly pushes pellets through barrel.

Cross hairs will be visible through the viewer goggles and will allow the pilot to target through the camera. (Programming will be required to add this feature.)

Other uses for this design

Customers want options for their drones and a design like this will broaden the market.
Affixed with a night vision camera, a pilot can deter pests from their property at night.
Aligned with the proper software the drone could operate as an autonomous security system for a residency.
You can even get into Combat Droning(TM) through 1 on 1 events.

The possibilities are endless and I will continually perfect the mechanics.

comments.text: The CO2 cartridge isn't 120 psi, it's about 800 or 900! You see, when you connect the cartridge to a bike wheel, it leaves the wheel at about 120 psi. However, the CO2 is much more compressed inside the cartridge (as there is less volume, the pressure isn't 120 psi but 900 psi!). The solenoid won't work with such high pressures; it will just let the air out (if it doesn't actually explode xD).
comments.author: Jabamun01

comments.text: Google Model Warship Combat. They use homemade BB guns to sink each other's boats (balsa wood sides) and have a variety of firing methods, and a few commercially available, extremely small systems. It's a well solved problem, with solenoids or micro servos used as actuators.
comments.author: Jabamun01

comments.text: I'm sure they don't use 800 psi CO2 cartridges with 120 psi solenoids, as thinkpool does in his project...
comments.author: gchristopher

comments.text: I think they use the same commercial airsoft cartridges as everyone, and their solenoid-controled systems run at 150 psi. Here's a 150psi regulator:
comments.author: Jabamun01

comments.text:
Thank you for your interest in this project
We are using a low compression CO2 cartridge that works with the solenoid valve. Ultimately we would like to use the high compression cartridge so we designed a micro solenoid valve that runs on 6V. This micro valve will solve your dilemma but in order to get it manufactured, the Chinese producers want an order of 100K units.
Its seems that everyone including yourself wants a drone of this design so we plan to acquire funding and develop the Drone Combat culture. We've even pitched the concept to a network that requested a demo of the show. The Combat Drone show will pit teams against each other through 4 challenges and ending in a 4 on 4 drone battle royal. We are hoping to pitch the concept using the Teal Sport as the flagship drone. Let me know your ideas we are willing to work together.
So we ask everyone to support this project so that we can get this off the ground. We accept any support from drone enthusiates like yourself.
comments.author: Jabamun01

comments.text: Wouldn't this cause bad weight distribution and unbalance the drone? I get that MAYBE the C02 tank and servo would be balanced by the BB's, but as you shoot, you would loose weight on one side. Also, the discharge of high pressure air would shake and push the drone. Newton's laws. Nice concept, but ultimately counter intuitive.
comments.author: DragonRundell

comments.text:
Thank you for your comment.
You have a keen eye and weight distribution was taken into consideration. If you look closely you will notice that the heavier components (Pneumatic valve and CO2 cartridge) are positioned closer to the center. Secondly the force required to propel a .12 gram pellet can easily be absorbed by the drone. We are continually improving this design and would appreciate any suggestions on balancing, etc. We can't wait to display the prototype. Thanks
comments.author: DragonRundell

comments.text: First of all, this would be awesome...if you make it please post videos!  One question though, it looks like you are simply piping the CO2 into the pellet reservoir and hoping a pellet finds the exit?  ...seems extremely unpredictable/unreliable at best.  Am I missing something?  Nice work on your drafting!
comments.author: kgmoney00

comments.text:
Thanks for the comment.
The simplicity of the design is critical in order to keep the weight down. The uniqueness of the pellets is that they will follow where ever the air flows. Take a look at these Youtube videos.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nBst0muSthI

comments.text: Thanks for the video, I might have to try that! :)  Simplicity is certainly key here and your point about the weight of the pellets makes sense.  On the other hand they had a lot more air to work with in the video.  I don't know, you've certainly convinced me it's worth at try!  Good luck! :)

description.text: a surfboard

Printer:

dremel idea builder

A friend has an annual Chocolate party, with guests invited to bring a chocolate concoction.

We decided to bring marshmallow pops. But how to present them? Well, I had this new 3D printer, so let's make a holder in the shape of a chocolate chip.

Note that if you look at it in OpenSCAD, the marshmallow pops are modeled so you can check the spacing.

Chip.* is the 2D cross section of the chip.
Holes.* are a secondary model to test the fit of your particular sticks.

Printer:

Craftbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Balance

The holder is pretty light. If it's only got a single marshmallow pop in it, it'll tip over. Double-stick foam tape held it nicely to a plastic plate.

Marshmallow Pops Ingredients
  • Full-sized marshmallows
  • Paper sticks, e.g. https://www.amazon.com/Cake-Pop-Sticks-300-Count-Lollipops/dp/B01MXYYL1L
  • Melting chocolate
  • Stuff to add: sprinkles, coconut, nuts, pepper flakes, et cetera
Marshmallow Pops Instructions
  1. Put marshmallows on sticks.
  2. Melt chocolate
  3. Dip marshmallows in chocolate.
  4. Roll marshmallows in toppings.
  5. Refrigerate.
  6. Eat.

Curves

I drew the curves in Inkscape because I kind of knew how to, and could get it to export into a form that OpenSCAD would import.

Today, I would probably just use Bezier functions directly in OpenSCAD.

Hole depth

The hold depth values include a great deal of fudge. I tweaked them until they were right. They try to scale with the model, but may not handle extreme changes in the parameters.

Cake Pops

Modeling cake pops instead of marshmallow pops is left as an exercise for the reader.

title: Functional Smoke/Gas Mask Respirator

description.text:
Great mini gas and smoke respirator that fits in your pocket great for emergency and men with beards!
There are lots of pictures to show you the way the filters are prepared (NO GLUE OR SCREWS REQUIRED) NOTE! There are 2 types of adapters to choose from Flush fit or Extended.

Items Required:
1 X 6mm Airsoft BB
Activated Charcoal (For Gas or Air Filters)
Cotton Makeup Removal Pads
Electric Tape

Instructions:
1) print all the parts once ( Filter pieces X 2 each)
2) Insert a 6mm Airsoft ball in the one way valve hole in the main body.
3) Press the one way valve cover to the main body.
4) Fill filter, 1st layer Cotton Makeup Pad, 2nd layer Activated Charcoal, 3rd layer Cotton Makeup Pads X 2.
5) Wrap the filter Top with electric tape to get an air tight seal then Press the Top & Bottom together, make 2 sets.
6) Press the 2 filters to the Adapters.
7) Attach the filters to the main body when in use and make sure the one way valve is facing UP!.
!!!For Emergency Use Only!!!
Version 2 is out https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2645635

!New update coming soon, filter housing for the following filters below:
https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/10Pcs-5N11-N95-Particulate-Filter-Respirator-Cotton-Gas-Mask-6200-6800-7502/201914499346?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/10pcs-5-packs-3M-2091-particulate-filter-P100-for-6000-7000-series-respirator/272204476147?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649
ADDED 3M P100 FILTER ADAPTORS
!Don't forget to check out my other designs and Follow my weekly KooKoo uploads, Enjoy ;)

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

5 shells

comments.author: RailGunner23

comments.text: Neighter, what kills you is lack of oxigen and any cartridge mask wont help with that.  You'll have clean lungs but you'll still pass out.  For fire situation you need something with an independent air source either a long hose to outside or compressed air bottle. This might be usefull for small paint jobs or work in dust even tear gaz if you can pinch your noze tight and don't mind a good weeping and some iritation.  Just don't go die in the fire thinking a gas mask will let you breathe properly.

comments.text: Yes that's a great idea :)  its a lot cleaner solution, its also used in water filters to filter out most of the harmful stuff,  My next project is going to be a survival water filter using charcoal and Iodine crystals, I'm testing it today before I publish the files.
comments.author: WarHawk8080

comments.text: yep and that's why you have to be careful with what you are buying. The activated charcoal for fluids is something different than the one for gasses.
comments.author: mussy

comments.text: Activated carbon attracts and holds organic chemicals from vapor and liquid streams cleaning them of unwanted chemicals. It does not have a great capacity for these chemicals, but is very cost effective for treating large volumes of air or water to remove dilute concentrations of contamination. For a better perspective, when individuals ingest chemicals or are experiencing food poisoning, they are instructed to drink a small amount of activated carbon to soak up and remove the poisons. (THERE IS NO DIFFERENCE)
comments.author: Rabulist

comments.text: Thanks for the advice I'm sure you are more qualified than me, I just did my research online
comments.author: mussy

comments.text: I'm an environmental engineer and I work with activated charcoal on a regular basis. There ARE different products for use in liquids and for use in gasses. Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying, that the charcoal for liquids won't work with gasses at all, but it won't work as good as the one specifically made to be used in gasses.

description.text:
Original Source: https://grabcad.com/library/military-warthog-1

What I've done to this file:

  • Split and cleanup scrap split parts.
  • I split it to make it use less support and so I could use a different color.
  • Designed a windshield (independent stl file, not in full body model.)
  • Fixed misc. file errors with meshmixer.

I'm not totally certain if the splits fit together correctly. I will be printing this myself soon.

There is a problem you may notice. If you don't already know what it is, then you should stop reading since you didn't notice, and if you didn't notice, then they wont annoy you.

The seats in the split body do not look like the seats in the main body. This is since splitting the part created some errors. I have attempted to fix these in mesh mixer, but I'm not knowledgeable enough to get them fully flat.

author: wilsey

description.text:
Good, good...it's Emperor Palpatine's Cane! There's surprisingly little canon or Legends material around this prop, but it looks cool so I modeled it and now you, yes you, can 3D print it if you so choose.

There are six pieces total. Each piece is labeled with its part number and also (except for part 1) is labeled where the previous piece should be stacked. So for example, 2 is labeled "2" on top but also has "1" on the bottom so you can more easily find the correct orientation for that part.

All parts are in the orientation I printed them and personally I used support generated in Cura for 6 which is, admittedly, a lot of support material. Feel free to play around with the orientation and let me know what worked best for you!

comments.text: I was SO excited to find this model! It looks amazing and I'm planning to print one up for actual daily use (with Carbon Fiber). But when I printed the bottom two pieces, I couldn't get them to connect. Are you willing to share the complete, single-solid version of the cane in a format that I might be able to slice myself? I've also got a CR-10 so would plan to print it in fewer pieces to reduce joint strain. Thanks so much for making this available to us!

author: Jetfire69

description.text:
Please see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1862570 for the remaining parts, 20 equilateral triangles are needed to form a globe. Not included here.

Recreated the icosahedron_insert_v04 with FreeCAD using only the Part workbench.
The STL of version v04 seems to have a face inclination angle of 52.0° which results in 59.5° corners of the triangles. For correct 60° triangles we use 52.623° inclination here.

The holes are replaced by pockets for neodym magnets of 8mm diameter, 2mm high.

There are two versions of the pieces, one (_cyl) has a cylindrial pocket for connecting magnet, centering it precisely. Not sure if that precision is helpful. In cas it is not, there is a second (_tri) version, that has a large triangular cutout, giving the connecting piece more freedom.

For both, there is a positioning aid included, that help gluing the touching magnet on the right spot.

The FreeCAD source is included to allow parametric modifications.

Math

Thanks to wolframalpha and some python, all this math became a brief excercise.
The radius p of the incircle of a regular pentagon is

p = 1./(2*math.sqrt(5-2*math.sqrt(5)))

The height h of a regular triangle is

h = math.sqrt(3)/2

So the inclination angle phi that we need is

phi = math.acos(p/h)/math.pi*180
90-phi = 52.62263185935032°

You'll find that number in the rotation of the fusion objects that create the 5 triangular faces. The faces come down from a vertical position.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in Inland Green and Inland Light Brown PLA.

description.text:
It's a puzzle box, based on a design by Osanori Yamamoto. It's called Identical Twins. The goal is to fit the two identical pieces inside of the base.

As a bonus, you can also print the Tetrahaedral (triangle shape) to create The Cell puzzle with the same base. Try to get the triangle shape in and out of the base through the small holes.

For a challenge, print the base as one piece. Otherwise, print as two pieces and join with glue. For a challenge, print the Tetrahaedral pointy side up (requires some great cooling). Otherwise, print pointy side down with supports.

While you're here, check out my other puzzle:
Pyramid Puzzle

If you can't solve this and want to give up, you can message me on Thingiverse, and I'll send you the link to the Youtube video with the solution.

Printing:
If you try to scale this model up or down, the tolerances will be affected.

Make sure that you print two of the Twin pieces.

Your printer must be capable of printing accurately on all axis in order for the puzzle pieces to fit properly. If you have a Wanhao I3, Monoprice Maker Select, or other cheap I3 clone, you may not be aware that your printer does not print in the Z axis properly as it comes from the factory. You need to fix your Z steps per mm or scale down the model on the Z axis to 98.7654%. If your first layer is too squished, you will probably need to trim off the brim. The pieces are intentionally snug.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print two of the Twin pieces.

Your printer's tolerances need to be good. If you're printing with a Wanhao I3, Monoprice Maker Select, or other clone, you're going to need to fix your Z steps per mm or scale the model on the Z axis only to 98.7654 %.

Print the Tetrahaedral with supports. Print the base with supports if you print it as one piece. Otherwise, print WITHOUT supports.

Printed in Inland Green and Inland Light Brown PLA.

Assembly

Assemble the base with superglue.

description.text:
2 Piece 50mm blower fan mount and duct for BIBO Touch X Dual. This will likely work with a number of other printers with a similar dual extruder head design. To mount, remove the OEM 40mm fan, keep the screws or replace with shorter screws. If you don't have a matching plug for the 50mm blower you can always clip and solder the plug on like I did.

To mount I only used the left bolt to hold it all. I have printed about 40 hours this way and it has not moved at all. Just to be safe I left and oversized hole where the other screw would go so that you could run a screw into the right mount to act as an anti-rotation pin if needed.

This can be printed with out without supports. I added supports and just knocked them out but they are not necessary the way its sliced. If you use the gcode provided you can print it as is on the BIBO. Its set to use the right extruder with PLA and just warms the left extruder to keep it from knocking the part loose. Or you can re-slice but there is no need to. If you slice it yourself and use anything other than Simplify you will likely need the supports.

The duct section just slides right into the mount and is held by gravity/friction. No glue or tape is required. This seems to have greatly improved the airflow and has shown a noticeable improvement in print quality.

Printer:

BIBO Touch X Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

75%

description.text: A desktop planter I made to house my $5 Home Depot golden barrel cactus. Kind of looks like a sea turtle crossed with a tiny baby dragon. Makes a great traveling companion and gains the ability to fly after 6 months.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%
I designed this planter mostly using Sculpting tools in Fusion360. Pretty neat!

This is a design that I have started now in CAD though it was started in my head a long time ago. I will continue to update this as I continue with the model.

The impeller fan is part of a parametric design project of a water jet pump. I have been playing with various design concepts to see what is necessary to model various fan blades as ideally as possible all while maintaining the flexibility of parametric modelling. It is 90mm in diameter.

This was the first fan type. It was inspired by the CFM Leap engine blade design. Of course not to any standard that replicates even a smidgen of the time and energy that is necessary to produce such a wonderful piece of work that is the Leap Engine.

All of the blades that I will upload will designed on the basis of being able to be fabricated from a 3 axis mill/router setup with the end goal to manufacture the blades from recycled HDPE plastic.

The purpose of the fan is to pump water. Which this blade is not designed for. The ultimate fan will more than likely have 3 - 5 blades and with a much higher pitch and blade area. This was just a fun exercise to get into the swing of the design, and as well produce some products for the 3D printing community to play with :)

I have not printed it as of yet, only sliced it up to produce GCODE using Cura software. It requires a small portion of the bottom hub to be cut off (use inbuilt function in slicer) so as to begin the blade on the build plate, otherwise you will require some high density support to print the blades properly. From my assessment thus far I am certain it will print nicely given the correct slicing parameters.

Be sure to comment and let me know what you think of the idea. I truly appreciate any feedback given.

comments.text: I used HobbyKing PLA at 210 degrees, 40% infill, printed at .3 resolution. printed with the spurs down. The first one I printed, one of the spurs broke off.... I was printing at 20% for the prototype, so for the next one I printed at 40% and added the domes next to the battery box at the top of each spur.  The weather in Oregon is cold so I only have 3 flights on the carbon cub but it held up just fine.  I fly the cub like my 3D planes, hammer heads, hovering, rolls, loops, Knife edges and it held up fine.  What part is breaking? I printed this on the CR-10S. I just replaced the file, another one, I viewed it on thingiverse and it looked like maybe there was a space between the dome and the battery box.  I had no problem with the one I printed but if there was any gap it's gone now.  Thanks for letting me know.

description.text:
The fun of this print is that it looks like it should simply fall apart in your hand, but in actual fact it is very difficult if not impossible to take apart. Because of this it is kind of fun to fidget with, there are lots of different angles and shapes and it feels very loose.

I include the word "puzzle" in the name because it is held together with keys/tabs/knobs that look just like a jigsaw puzzle. Everyone who picked it up assumed it was a puzzle, and so I spent a lot of time making it possible to take apart. Unfortunately the ease or impossibility of taking it apart is very dependent on the quality of the print.

I designed this in Openscad, but I did not mark this as customizable because it is incredibly dependent on the how the settings interact whether it can be disassembled or not. I have included the source file so people can see how I did it, and possibly work on making it customizable.

I included the word "Puck" because I am from Canada, and it reminded me of a hockey puck. I doubt it would last very long in a hockey game.

I include the word "Staircase" because that seems to be the other word that my family were always using to describe the shape it makes. I was thinking of calling it a "Penrose Staircase" as it is possible to make the steps continue to infinity by dropping the top stair so that it meshes and becomes the bottom stair. Technically the Penrose staircase is an optical illusion, so I decided not to use that name.

The inspiration came from a YouTube video of a cast metal puzzle, but this is a little less of a puzzle and more of a fidget puck that sometimes looks like a staircase, and this is made of plastic which is much softer than cast metal, which causes different problems. I also did not re-create the shape of that puzzle(and to be fair, I didn't re-create the actual shape of a hockey puck either). Note that I did not have one of Hanayama puzzles to look at or measure, this was created entirely by me.
You can find the video by searching "Hanayama Cast Spiral Puzzle" but beware, the video that pops up is showing the solution to that puzzle. The solution to this puzzle is similar to the Hanayama puzzle, but it is possible that your printer will result in more possible solutions, or perhaps no solution at all.

Please send me a comment if you can print one that can be solved.

description.text:
Carpets / Rug Grips , As we have had problems keeping thick heavy mats in place I made some printable grips, Spikes on one side & using double-sided tap on the other & have worked better than expected.
There are 3 sizes, 200 x 65, 250 x 65 & 275 x 65, To almost any size printer, have found longer thinner more flexible the way to go rather than a Large square.
These might show a little more depending on how thick your carpet / Rugs are & of course the thinner the double-sided tape the better.
Clean the back of the Grip with methylated spirits & apply double-sided tape, Stick the spike side into carpet & lay your rug on top, Stomping &/ or a rubber mallet works well.
ABS, PLA PETG Filaments have all worked for this project.
Layer 0.2mm, 15% Infill, Speed 50mm/s, Doesn't need to look a million dollars so whatever speed you can get away with taking care that the spikes turn out properly.

remixed_from.author: vernierroger
remixed_from.title: Belt Tensioner Axe X Anet A6

title: Belt Tensioner X Axis Anet A6

description.text:
The original belt tensioner by vernierroger is a very clever idea/design. However, I had some trouble fitting the internal components into my A6 X carriage. Also, I was confused as to what hardware (nuts and bolts) I was supposed to use to make it all work. So, I re-worked it using vernierroger parts as the starting point. I made a little more space for everything and changed the design so you could use spare nuts and bolts that came with the A6 printer to assemble it (instead of having to go to the hardware store and buy something).

In detail:

  • The "edited frame" remains the same.

  • I modified the tendeur/stretcher slightly (I call it "pulley block") to accommodate the nuts and bolts I wanted to use. For the pulley axle, I used a spare M3x30 flat head bolt (cut to approximately 15 mm of thread) and M3 nut. For the tension bolt, I used another M3x30 flat head bolt with a nut jammed up against the head. I pushed the tension bolt down into the slot on the pulley holder. (It's a tight fit, but it needs to be so it does not rotate.) I made the pulley block slightly less tall as well, so it does not bind against the top and bottom plates. Once printed, I filed the sides of the pulley holder just a bit, so it slides smoothly.

  • I modified the "knob", so you can put a hidden M3 nut inside of it. Start the print and figure out then it's going to be about 80 percent complete. That's when you'll put the nut inside. When it starts making the hex-shaped space for the nut, get ready. Wait until the space for the nut is about 2mm deep (about the thickness of a nut) and then pause the print. As the print head moves away, put an M3 nut into the cavity and then restart the print. The print head will come back and print the remainder of the knob around the nut.

    I made a video but unfortunately, it's not very good quality. Hopefully, it will still help to demonstrate this explanation.
    https://youtu.be/07crnQ8DOuU

    Since the nozzle oozes some filament while you pause, you may get a small defect in your print. To minimize this, I give the filament a little shove into the print head when it's on its way back. It also helps to slow down the feed rate on the printer when you do this process, so you don't miss the opportunity to place the nut. To do that on an A6, turn the controller knob CCW while it's displaying the main information screen.

  • I created a new part called "Middle Plate". It's a replacement for the acrylic plate that holds the original idle pulley. I made it thinner, so there is more space for the pulley block to be installed in the carriage.

In addition to the printed parts you will need:

2x M3x30 flat head bolts (Anet A6 spare)
2x M3 nut (Anet A6 spare)
(You will gain 3x nuts and 1x bolt from the parts you take out.)

Printer:

Anet A6

Yes

No

0.15 mm layers

35% ish

title: Onitama Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Onitama is a two-player, perfect information abstract game with a random starting set-up. On a 5x5 board, both players start with five pawns on their side, with the main pawn in the middle. Each player has two open cards that each display a possible move for any of his pieces. There is a fifth card that cannot be used by either player.
On a player's turn, he chooses one of his cards, moves one of his pieces according to the chosen card, then replaces the card he used with the fifth card. The other player then chooses one of his cards, moves accordingly, and exchanges that card with this fifth card — which is, of course, the card the first player just used. Moving onto one of the opponent's pawns removes that pawn from the game. Taking the opponent's main pawn, or moving your main pawn into your opponent's main pawn's starting space, wins you the game.
I Harry Potter themed this make.
I have Remixed Tanya Wiesner's Harry Potter and Dumbledore into the player pawns.

I was making some pulleys for a tension-sensing end-of-filament sensor (still working on it... soon). Yes, I ended up having to keep upping the diameter of the pulley since filament doesn't like to bend in small radiuses!

But I thought someone else might be in need of some nice solid pulley designs. The distance within each pulley is 4mm (but the edges are tapered for strength, so 2mm or 1.75mm would be a good fit). There are three diameters here, 26mm, 35mm and 45mm (that's the diameter the string, filament, or belt rides on). You can use all those 608 bearings you have now eating up space since the fidget spinner craze had died down!

You'll need two halves for whichever pulley you make, and two end buttons (these buttons will space the outside of the pulley about 1.5mm from the surface the button gets mounted to). Best to put a drop of superglue inside the assembled halves. The larger sizes could also use a drop of superglue on the posts that hold the outsides together. Press the bearing in right after you put the glue on, putting these rings (assembed together) on a piece of waxed paper on a hard, flat surface. Push the bearing through hard till it meets flat against the same surface, that should keep everything square and make a good solid piece.

I've done some in PLA and in PET-G, should work ok with ABS too I imagine. Hope you find a use for these/

title: 1/10 Scale Camaro LS3 motor. Working model

description.text:
Update: after checking the scale it is actually closer to 1/10 scale. maybe a little larger.

Update: 11/23/2017 Added spark plugs, LS3 coils, Coil boot and spark plug boot. Coil Boots may have to enlarged depending on your printer settings. Spark plug boot is mis-labeled. the 90 degree boot goes to the plugs as seen in the pictures.

1/10 scale Camaro LS3 motor. this is a scaled down version of ericthepoolboy's 1/3 scale motor. The 1/10 scale down was initally done by Novel Mutations and redesigned by me to use 623 (10x3x4mm) bearings and 1.5mm screws. Screws can be sourced from www.rc4wd.com, ebay, or amazon. Most of the 1.5 screws I used was 1.5x 3mm (covers and surface screws, 6mm (crank bearing caps side bolts and Crank spacers), 8mm (crank), and 10mm (flywheel). Bearings were sourced from here https://www.banggood.com/10pcs-623ZZ-3x10x4mm-Ball-Bearings-Shielded-Radial-Bearings-p-1049663.html?rmmds=myorder&cur_warehouse=CN

1x2mm Neodymium magnets hold all the parts together. I found them on ebay.

The drive motor was sourced from a old HS-645 MG servo I had lying around. The drive gear is simply pushed on with a little CA glue.

Cams have to be printed with full support and bearing mounts need to be filed and sanded when done for a flush fit I used #18 brad nails and CA glue to assemble the cam.

The Air filter is printed out of TPU and is secured with a indent on the Air filter throttle body. It you are going to use PLA you migh have to file off the indent on the airfilter.

This is not a easy build. Expect to file, sand, shave, alter, and drill to make this build a working build. All the lifter holes have to be ported and the push rod holes have to be sized to what you are going to use. the pistons and the cylinders have to be sanded smooth.

You tube video https://youtu.be/NvuUL0jqNSs

Novel Mutations version can be found here.. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1996991

Rolling engine stand can be fount here... https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2657483

This is an old-fashioned wagon (or smaller cart) for use in 28mm games. There are 1-inch grid marks to aid in game movement (wagon is 2x4 squares, cart is 1x2). Horses not included.

Q&A:
Wait, so where do you put the wheels?
Get yourself some 1/16th inch wooden dowels and cut them to something like 2.25 inches. Glue that onto the bottom, then put the wheels onto the dowel and glue them in place; they're not going to be snug enough to spin without falling off. You'll want two axles for the wagon but you can probably get away with one axle for the cart.

Is the harness supposed to move?
Yeah, there's a print-in-place joint so that it can incline and rest on the shoulders of whatever animal minis you use. You'll want to loosen that before you glue it onto the wagon (which you should glue to the front of the wagon under the seat as far down as you can). It gave me just the right amount of movement, but if it doesn't bend or if it swings too loosely, play with your layer height.

What print settings did you use?
I did these on .3 layer height. Supports are definitely required for the harness and the wagon, but you shouldn't need them for the wheel or the cart.

What program did you design these in?
tinkercad.com is a free, in-browser, and stupidly easy-to-use 3D design program.

Look at that horse, that horse is amazing...
Totally not mine. You can find it here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29249. Needs scaling. You can use any mini of appropriate size though; there's no attachment points or anything designed to work with that specific horse. Oh, and the people riding in the cart are probably Reaper minis.

title: Sturdy Di3 v2.1 bracket for Thorped fan duct

description.text:
A somewhat overengineered bracket to attach Thorped's WANHAO i3 Fan duct to the X carriage of a version 2.1 Monoprice Maker Select / Wanhao Duplicator i3.

Design goals:

  • Attach to X carriage without requiring any drilling/tapping
  • Reduce torque on bottom bearing by attaching to both top and bottom bearings of X carriage
  • Provide clearance for larger custom X axis belt tensioners
  • Don't block the air intake of the radial fan
  • Print without slicer-added supports (a few twist-off supports are built in to recessed areas on the bottom of the print)

This bracket is designed specifically for this hardware version of this printer, and probably won't fit anything else.

The STL file for the fan duct that attaches to this bracket can be found on Thorped's WANHAO i3 Fan duct page and is called "Wanhao fan duct".

Required hardware:

  • (2) M3 x 10mm bolts
  • (2) M3 nuts
  • (2) M4 x 35mm bolts for top of bracket
  • (2) M4 x 25 or 30mm bolts for bottom of bracket*
  • (2) M4 x 25mm bolts to attach the fan
  • (4) M4 nuts (2 for top of bracket, 2 for fan)

*From the comments, different users report different lengths (25 vs 30mm) are appropriate for the bottom bolt. This could be a difference in measurement techniques - when buying new bolts, note that measurements on the packaging typically are for the threaded portion only and don't include the head.

Thanks is due to the contributors in the comments (tehgreedo and rcollins927) for bolt measurement feedback - I neglected to measure those in my installation, as I cut them to fit from 60mm M4 bolts I had lying around.

Other mods

This Thing is part of a set of mods I've designed for this printer - here's the rest of the set, I hope you find them useful:

  • Heated bed stabilizers
  • Cold end fan shroud

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Shouldn't need any additional supports.

Clean up prints
  • Test fit the radial fan into the duct and trim the duct as necessary until the fan fits snugly into the duct.
  • Use pliers to grab and twist off the four oval supports around the bottom of the bracket.
Attach the fan duct to the bracket
  • Push one M3 nut into the deep recessed hole in the bracket (a small screwdriver may help).
  • Thread a M3 bolt up from the bottom of the corresponding fan duct hole and engage the deep recessed M3 nut.
  • Finish attaching the fan duct with a second M3 bolt and nut.
  • Tighten M3 bolts until snug.
Attach the duct/bracket combo to the X carriage
  • From the front of the printer, insert M4 x 35mm bolts through the topmost two holes in the X carriage. Thread the bolts all the way through until they stop - they should now stick out the back of the X carriage.
  • Slide the fan bracket + fan duct onto the top two bolts and loosely secure with two M4 nuts.
  • From the back of the printer, screw two M4 x 30mm bolts through the bottom holes in the bracket.
  • Tighten the top two nuts and bottom two bolts.
Attach the fan to the duct/bracket
  • Insert the fan into the duct. It should press-fit in place and the mounting holes should line up.
  • Route the wires from the fan as necessary.
  • From the back of the printer, insert two M4 x 25mm bolts through the fan and through the bracket.
  • Secure fan bolts with M4 nuts and tighten.

description.text:
I was looking for a way to use a Ryobi 18v battery as a power source on a project I was doing and came across {Battery Holder for Ryobi 18V battery by Walpeup } he did all the hard work I just tweaked it to fit my needs.
  I deleted his cable tie tabs and added lugs so that the terminal can be screwed to the base, I made the base just a hair deeper because I had problems with locking the battery into it on the first one I printed out, and I created a box so it could be screwed together and mounted onto my project.
  I didn't make screw holes because I am lazy and it would have taken more time to line things up and make holes in tinkercad then it would to just mark em and drill them by hand
 You can look up Walpeup's design for info about the battery terminals he used and his print settings

Anet A8

Doesn't Matter

Yes

.2

Infill:

75

Notes:

I'm still kinda new to 3D printing so my settings may not make sense to you experts but they worked for me (edit) these settings worked for the base and the terminal but the enclosure warped badly and split. i am pretty sure it was due to a temputure drop and drafts in my house but who knows. it wasnt anything a little sanding and fuseing couldnt fix. i broke each peice at the splits and sanded them flat then diped the edges into acetone for a few seconds and fused/glued them back together (gotta love ABS) i fused all the peices together this way then drilled and screwed them.

description.text: This is something I whipped up while between calls at work. I am learning 3d printing and design, mostly in my downtime at work, so I did this for practice and to avoid the "this isn't work related!" talk.
Designed in tinkercad.

At long last (to me anyway) the Cobra SNAKE battle suit. I used a “borrowed” toy and a pair of 6 inch calipers to create this 3D file. As usual, the file is modeled at the size of the actual toy but is intended to be printed at 25%. If you print this larger or smaller it may have too much or too little detail.

The toy came with four weapons; a missile, claw hand, machine gun, and flame thrower. I’ve included 8 different files for the arms so you can choose the weapon configuration you want. I could have made the arms swappable but PLA is so inexpensive it doesn’t matter to me…I just made more of them. Also note that the arms and legs are glued in place, allowing for some variation in poses. It looks a little more natural if both legs are not pointing straight ahead. Also, the shoulder attachment point can be modified (with a file or sandpaper) to point the arm in or out a little bit.

Much respect and gratitude to past and present members of our Armed Forces, you are the “Real American Heroes”. Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and make silly little toys like these.
Also a ‘thank you’ to R.S. for loaning the toy to me. This was a tricky one and I’d never have been able to model it without having it in my hands.

This file is free to download. Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”. Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model. You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use. If you have downloaded this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission. Thank you for respecting the rights of the original copyright holder.

title: King Size Filter Tube Cigarette Tamper

description.text:
Ever been dumb enough to not check the ebay listing before buying a cigarette filter tube packer? Apparently I have, and the Shargio one I bought didn't come with one of these and I couldn't find one online so here it is in case you lost yours or made my same mistake.

This is a king size cigarette tube injector tamper tool for packing down the tobacco in the machine before injecting the tubes. It should work in any king size machine, and you could probably stretch the length another 25-30mm for 100s if you wanted to. Works perfectly in my Shargio and should be the same for all the others.

description.text:
The GI Joe Armadillo, a tankette armed with four “cluster cannons”. I used an old toy and a pair of 6 inch calipers to create this 3D file. As usual, the file is modeled at the size of the actual toy but is intended to be printed at 25%. If you print this larger or smaller it may have too much or too little detail.

There are two versions of the treads: A shorter version that matches how the toy was designed. There is also a 1 inch longer “extended” version in case you think the shorter treads make the tank look silly.

The chassis should be printed right side up with supports. Be careful cleaning around the roll bar as it is delicate.
The turret should be printed right side up with supports.
The guns should be horizontal for printing, they are stronger than if pointed straight up. After printing they are glued to the turret at the desired angle.
The track assembly should be printed upside down.

I used an old toy and a pair of 6 inch calipers to create this 3D file. As usual, the file is modeled at the size of the actual toy but is intended to be printed at 25%. If you print this larger or smaller it may have too much or too little detail.

The chassis should be printed right side up with supports.
The turret should be printed right side up with supports.
The front tires and treads should be printed with the hubcaps pointing up. No supports needed.
The ski missiles are printed with the ski down and supports turned on.
The chin piece is printed upside down and glued to the underside of the chassis. (see picture) If I had made this piece a part of the chassis then it would have left a lot of support material to clean off, which I didn’t like. A separate part was the lesser of two evils.

title: Mobile Mount for Galaxy S7 (with case)

description.text:
This is a phone holder I made for my Samsung Galaxy S7. The initial goal was to make a custom fit for my car's dashboard (Toyota Camry 7th Gen), however I made a generic mount that could tilt instead, as this positioned the phone at the same level and angle as the head unit. Furthermore, it could be mounted using nothing more than double sided tape.

The design was made in Fusion 360, and is parametric so you could probably adapt it to your phone, However the ports on the underside would need to be repositioned to suit your phone. I may revisit this design to suit a naked S7 instead (without any case).

The back plate mounts to any flat surface using an adhesive, and connects to the actual holder using an M4 bolt and nut. Light tightening with a washer would result in a tiltable holder, while tightning with no washer so that the plastic is bitten into would result in a fairly permanent position.

title: Anet A8 X Carriage dual extruder stock and e3d
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I reworked this design to work better as I found some issues with version 1 (namely cooling of the extruder motor and heat retention in general causing warping of the carriage.
I wanted a carriage that would dual nozzles. I wanted to keep the stock direct extruder which works well with flexible filament and to keep weight down I went with e3d and a remote extruder. I designed z probe sensors (18mm) to mount on the side closer to the nozzle tips for easier bed leveling.
The e3d can be adjusted up and down to get the nozzle alignment right.
This carriage uses 16mm polymer bushings.
various 2mm and 3mm screw hardware is needed to assemble
If anyone is interested in more in more details about assembling this leave a comment and I will get back to you as soon as I can.
NOTES: the e3d carrier may need some tweaking for size (especially if you get a clone)
The fan nozzle has been re-designed to mount the fan in the back to provide better balance.
Once again...drop a line in the comments and I can provide more details and the freecad file if so desired.

Anet A8

Yes

description.text:
I printed Kappie's nice Christmas tree design. I printed them using Monoprice natural PLA at 100%, 125% and 150% to create several in different sizes. I wasn't happy with the way the tea lights (Home Depot color change LED tea lights) sat unswe the tree, so I mixed up a holder for the tea light that had a centering ring for the tree to sit properly positioned on the tea light. I printed the holders using Inland Forest Green PLA. You'll note there are three size centering rings which should work with the three percentages listed above when printing Kappie's design (www.thingiverse.com/thing:1202114).

I printed using supports at 50% infill. The orientation of the design reduces the amount of support printed and they print fairly quickly.

IMPORTANT SAFETY NOTICE: This is not intended for the candle style tea lights. This is not to be used around open flames. I would hope that is obvious to anyone wanting to print this item.

title: Cold air intake for CPU cooling.

description.text:
A cold air intake for CPU cooling on MSI B250M Bazooka motherboards, and other motherboards with similar CPU positions. Specifically it's designed to be a direct fit in Komplett 2017 Winter Gamer PC:
https://www.komplett.no/product/11066/pc-nettbrett/komplett-pc/komplett-gamer/komplett-winter-gamer?offerId=KOMPLETT-310-11066#

If this doesn't fit your PC, then at least look at it as an inspiration for your own ducting designs.

This intake alone lowered the full Prime95 load temperature from 90°C to 75°C on my I7-7700 CPU. It does this by letting the CPU fan blow cold air directly from the outside of the case instead of recycling the hot air inside the case. Useful if you have a small heat sink and want better performance without buying more parts.

Trimming of the square end will most likely be required with other motherboards than the MSI B250M Bazooka. The short tube part fits in the opening of the duct and can be printed to any height by changing the X height in the slicer and works as a spacer if your heat sink and fan are lower than mine is.

The round end fits over an Akasa AK-959CU 96 mm outer diameter heat sink fan and no other means of attachment is necessary with that fan. Hot glue is a good was of attaching it to other fans. If it's very hard to get it on I suggest cutting more slots around the edge in addition to the one already there on the model. I had to do this on mine, which is a slightly tighter version. I made the diameter 1% bigger on the one I uploaded.

My cooler:
https://www.banggood.com/Akasa-AK-959CU-Double-Platform-Radiator-CPU-Cooling-Fan-Cooler-Designed-For-Intel-LGA775-LGA115X-p-1228644.html?p=HD240528697332015103&cur_warehouse=CN

I recommend adding a filter to the intake:
https://www.banggood.com/Akasa-Aluminium-Fan-Filters-Fine-Mesh-for-8cm-9_2cm-12cm-14cm-PC-Fans-p-1209017.html?p=HD240528697332015103

cold air comes in the front, hot air out the back rises and gets sucked in straight onto the cpu which is then trapped with no where to go so just swirls round heating up. also there's not a lot pulling it out the back only the psu fan.

title: Schacht bobbin with sheep head embellishment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This bobbin is designed to be used with the Schacht Sidekick spinning wheel, but may work on other wheels as well.

The bobbin consist of three parts: two discs and a tube. The parts are screwed together using threads to avoid having to glue them permanently.

Print Settings

Printer: Anet A8
Layer height: 0.2 mm
Raft: no

The discs

  • Support: yes
  • Infill: 20%

The tube

  • Support: no
  • Infill: 100%

Post-Printing

  1. The flyer shaft hole in the tube must be drilled open using an 8.1mm drill. After that use a bit of type 600 sand paper to smoothen out the inner surface of the drill hole.
  2. If the discs wobble, please make sure that all support material is removed and that the discs are screwed tightly onto the tube.

Legal & Acknowledgements

Schacht Sidekick is an registered name of Schacht Spindle Company.

The sheep head embellishment is based on an icon made by Freepik from www.flaticon.com that is licensed under CC 3.0 BY

title: TronXY X5S Z Max limit switch holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Thing to mount a makerbot style limit switch (I used mechanical, i think the optical ones are the same board size) at ZMax on a tronxy X5S.

You'll need M5 bolts & Tnuts *2 to mount to the bottom extrusion, 2 M3 screws to mount the board and to turn your standard M3 'limit bolt' upside down (I reccomend adding a nylock to hold it).

You'll also likely need to remove your ZMin switch (or use this on the opposite corner) so there isn't any interferance (I snapped mine off so I could still use the Y position.)

title: Pegaso 1080 for Mr.Crankyface's Chassis (Rear Box)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This body is specially designed for Mr.CrankyFace chassis. You can find al the mechanical parts in the following links:

Frame: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1695694
Rear Axle: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1676173
Front Axle: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1651135
Gearbox: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704988
Central Gearbox: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1680949

I also designed these shock absorbers specially for this truck. I've tested them and they work pretty good.

Shock absorbers: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2252957

For this part you will need a 360 x 186 x 5mm plywood in order to make the box base. You will also need more plywood to cover all the other parts and make them stronger.

Notice that some parts need to be printed several times:

- Front column x2
- Rear column x2
- Central column x4
- Side part x6

All the other parts just need to be printed once.

Feel free to remix the rear box in order to make it 100% printable or whatever you want.

Here you will only find the cab files. In order to build the entire Pegaso 1080 you will also need this other parts:

Cab: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2627079
Wheels: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2648302
Accessories: (In progress)

title: TronXY X5S (CReality CR10) E3D V6 Mount with Piezo Sensing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 28/11/17: Parts have been updated to be easier to print, and allow for a 5015 radial fan (no fan part included).

For now I have only included 27mm version, if anyone wants to use 20mm it will still work with this mount, just centre the piezo disc on the back.
</end update>
This is a more or less final but still work in progress mount for an E3D V6 style 'groove mount' Hotend to a TronXY X5S. It should work (but isn't tested as I don't have one, if you do please post a comment/make) on other machines with similar mounts (from what I can tell, all the TronXY printers, the Creality CR10 and maybe a couple of others).

The X Endstop mount is for a Makerbot Style PCB endstop. The stock one will work, but you'll need to find a mounting solution for it (self tappers or hot glue will both work fine).

If you want to make any changes this is designed in onshape, so you can edit it for free (as in beer) here
If you do so please link the updated version back to me (particularly if it includes different fan shrouds etc).

Instructions for setup with MKS Sbase/Smoothieware are on my blog

Update 12/11/17 - reaslied i'd made an error inthe file uploaded, fixed stls included.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This is likely to be quite material sensitive. I printed in PETG 4 walls, 4 top/bottom 15% infill. PLA almost certainly won't work.
You will need supports for the back, which needs to be smooth, I'd suggest using an interface layer at around 60%

Build

Superglue the piezo of whichever size you're using to the relief in the back of the print after you've cleaned it up. Mount to printer of your choice.

author: Okavango

description.text:
This is a replacement internal 'cog' for the Nokia CR200 charger.

If you have one, and the arms have gone slack then there is a tiny little piece inside that has likely broken or cracked. There's a community discussion where codekaizen---01 has posted a diagram of the piece.

I used this, to make one up in Fusion 360. I had to clean it up a little by scratching the edges smooth with a scalpel, but it went right in and fits snug.

When re-assembling, crank the internal cog to wind the spring. 2.5 turns gives the arms decent tension. If you re-grease the inside, only use a little bit of grease. It prevents the mechanism from turning.

Step by Step repair Guide:
https://imgur.com/a/I8j0v

Nokia Manual:
https://www.manualslib.com/manual/574829/Nokia-Cr-200.html?page=4#manual

Microsoft Community Discussion:
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/mobiledevices/forum/mdaccessories/cr200-broken-plastic-guide/ddef2cbb-cc8c-4dc4-bb2a-db18209635f0

A metal one made by someone else you can get:
https://www.shapeways.com/product/9PWPDVCMQ/nokia-cr-200-replacement-cam

Magnetic holder to be installed directly on the Z-axis right side of the Anycubic I3 Mega. As the camera goes up as you print, the print head is always targeted. The parts to be printed contain the support with the insertion of 3 magnets (diameter 1cm, thickness 3mm) and its cover. The box for the camera is designed for a raspicam. A guide for passing the connecting cable through an Ikea Lack table, between the camera and the raspberry is provided.
