author: jimhigson

print_settings.Notes:: https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/original-prusa-i3-mk3-f30/temperature-extruder-motor-50-degrees-c--t12811.html

title: NEMA (extruder) motor rotation indicator (Prusa i3 MK2/MK2S/MK3)

description.text:
I always like to see what is going on with my printers. Sometimes I wonder what movement the extruder motor is making (extruding, retracting, slow, fast, etc.), which is not always so visible on the Prusa i3 MK2 / MK2S / MK3.

Hence I have designed an indicator that you can magnetically snap onto the axis of the NEMA extruder stepper motor. Just print the design, glue a magnet with some super glue onto it (let the glue dry...) and snap it on the motor (make sure to glue the magnet to the 'raised' side). These print in only a few minutes.

Just for the fun I designed a "Dutch Windmill" version. For the purist: unfortunately the extruder motor rotates clockwise when extruding while original Dutch windmills turn counter clockwise :-). Also added a version with smileys. Pls feel free to make your own design and do not forget to post a "made one"!

I have uploaded now 6 versions:

  • Indicator version for a 8x3mm Magnet
  • Windmill version for a 8x3mm Magnet
  • Smiley version for a 8x3mm Magnet
  • Lightning version for a 8x3mm Magnet
  • Indicator version for a 6x3mm Magnet**
  • "Turbine" version for a 8x3mm Magnet (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2802136)

** Note that I have not tested this 6x3mm magnet version; I am waiting for the magnets to be delivered :-) Update 15-01-2018: I finally managed to test the 6 mm magnet version. It is not a success for me (it rotates, but slips too much). I leave the design available since maybe it works for somebody else, but my recommendation is to use the versions with 8x3mm magnets.

Mikolas Zuza from Prusa Research has also posted an article about this indicator / visualizer on Prusa's website: https://www.prusaprinters.org/visualize-extruder-motor-movements/

https://youtu.be/cpXcXe8jRyE
https://youtu.be/R37Sh5CsHQE
https://youtu.be/YSM4HN9qsq4

Magnets:
http://www.ebay.nl/itm/Hot-Sales-N52-Super-Strong-Cylinder-Disc-Magnets-8-x-3mm-Rare-Earth-Neodymium/263071072275?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=562071935207&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

Edit 06-02-2018: In the comments below, Insanity682 pointed rightfully out that he posted already a magnetic attachable extruder indicator before me - of which I was not aware (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2285254), so credits to him.
Following this notification I could find that Tinkerer did something similar in 2013 already, so kudos to him/her(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119000) as well.
Maybe there are even more. Anyway, credits to whomever deserves it, I just hope people like it.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100

Notes:

I have printed some 30 hours or so with the indicator attached and have seen no negative effects. Initially I considered that potentially the temperature of the motor could be affected since this blocks the 8.5 mm hole in the motor which might vent some heat, however temperature measurements with an infrared thermometer does not show any significant temperature increase of the motor (in fact the temperature of the extruder motor is almost the same as those of the Z-axis stepper motors).

Update 15-01-2018: Many more hours printing later, no issues with the temperature. I also now have an MK3 which has a much higher extruder motor temperature (because of the Bondtech gears the motor just has to work a little harder). This is absolutely no issue according to Joseph Prusa: " Motors can work reliably up until 100°C". See: https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/original-prusa-i3-mk3-f30/temperature-extruder-motor-50-degrees-c--t12811.html

Puzzle magnétique en forme de cube assez ardu à reconstituer, il est constitué de 8 pièces aimantées avec des aimants de 1cm de diamètre de de 3 mm d'épaisseur. Pour repérer la polarité des aimants, installez dans le guide 2 aimants de polarités opposées, pour installer facilement les aimants dans les différentes pièces en respectant la polarité. Un fichier pdf explique le montage de chaque pièce.

Magnetic puzzle cube-shaped hard enough to restore, it consists of 8 magnetized pieces with magnets 1cm in diameter of 3 mm thick. To identify the polarity of the magnets, install in the guide 2 magnets of opposite polarity, to easily install the magnets in the different parts respecting the polarity. A pdf file explains the assembly of each piece.

Magnets link : https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/B00AAWEFPO

Edit :
Nouveau fichier pour le détrompeur et la base du cube (non incluse dans le fichier global)
New file for the key and cube base (not included in the global file)
Edit 2 :
Nouveaux fichiers pour la solution et la construction du cube avec explications plus claires du positionnement des faces d'aimants sur les pièces.
New files for the solution and the construction of the cube with clearer explanations of the positioning of the faces of magnets on the pieces.

comments.text:
Super cube !
Il n'est vraiment pas facile à reconstituer, c'est un vrai casse tête. Avec du filament bois, ça rend très bien.
Je conseille de positionner les éléments sur le lit de telle façon que les faces extérieure ne soient pas réalisés en contact avec le support. L'état de surface du cube fini est ainsi plus homogène (et plus beau !)
Merci pour le partage !

comments.text: I don't doubt that plastic can crush cans.  I'm not sure how well PLA would hold up, but if printed right I think ABS or PETG would work. I'd like to see a prototype printed first before I'd spend the time and filament getting this to work in some of the harder-to-print filaments.
